com.pb.sawdust.util.property

Class PropertyDeluxe

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.pb.sawdust.util.property.PropertyDeluxe
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    Emfac2011Properties

    public class PropertyDeluxe
extends java.lang.Object
    The PropertyDeluxe class provides a means to hold and retrieve properties in a more flexible manner than java.util.Properties. It provides the ability to load (and access) standard properties files, while augmenting them with namespaces, typing, and tokenizing.

    The namespace functionality allows properties to be nested within declared namespaces. Within a properties file, the namespaces are declared to start by including a line "+namespace_name", where "namespace_name" is the name of the namespace. A namespace ends by including a line "-namespace_name". If a namespace is never declared to end in a properties file, it is assumed to be valid from its start point through the end of the file. Namespace declarations do not need to be properly nested. Namespaces are agnostic about namespace ordering, and inherit the properties from the namespaces they contain. Property values set "further" within an namespace override the same property values set previously in the namespace hierarchy. In the following example, 

    
     +a
     p1 = 1
     +b
     p2 = 2
     -a
     p2 = 3
    property p1 is in namespace (a), and property p2 is in namespace (a,b). The following table summarizes the property values for various namespace combinations (N/A indicates the property is not present in the namespace):

    Namespace p1 p2
    (a) 1 -
    (b) - 3
    (a,b) - 2

    Although properties in PropertyDeluxe instances may be added/changed, the namespaces are fixed by the property resources read at construction time. Thus, if namespaces are required which do not have properties from the resources used at construction-time, they must be at least declared in the resources.

    The typing system provides the ability to specify the type of the value for a given property key. Any key with the form: 

    
     key(type) = value
    is assumed to be a typed key-value pair, where type specifies the type. The allowed type codes are:

    Type Code Type
    I int
    D double
    B boolean
    S String
    L List
    M Map

    The list and map type codes can be augmented with subtypes specifying their element types or key-value types, respectively. (Note: to avoid ambiguity, maps cannot use lists or maps as their key types.) For example, the type LI indicates a type of List<Integer>, and the type MBLLS indicates a type of Map<Boolean,List<List<String>>>.

    For the primitive types, the object wrapper's parse method is used to type-check and create the value (e.g. Integer.parseInt(String) for int). A string type will always pass type-checking, since properties are inherently strings. For list types, the syntax for values is a bracketed, comma-separated list: 

    
     [element1,element2,...]
    For map types, the syntax for values is a braced, comma-separated list of key-value pairs separated by a colon: 
    
     {key1:value1,key2:value2,...}
    For both lists and maps, whitespace within the elements/keys/values is retained in the resulting value elements (that is, whitespace around the commas is not stripped out). There is currently no way to escape commas for lists or maps.

    In addition to the type checking, this class provides methods to retrieve the property values as one of the above specified types. These methods do not require that the type be specified in the key, though this is recommended practice for fail-fast behavior (if the type is declared in the property file, and incorrectly specfied value will cause an excpetion to be thrown at construction time, as opposed to when the "getType" method is called).

    The tokenizing system allows token strings and replacement strings to specified in the properties, which are then used to detokenize the values in the properties. All tokens are of the form [token_specifier]token, where the token specifier is set at contruction (the default value is @@). For example, the following (default) token declaration in a property file: 

    
     @@my_token = hello
    when applied to the following property: 
    
     my.property = I said my_token
    will result in the property my.property having the value "I said hello". Tokens follow the same namespace nesting and overriding rules as properties; they will only apply within their namespaces and will override any previously declared tokens.

    A token is also available (within its namespace) as a regular property, where access to it is through its token name (sans the token specifier). It is also noted that tokens may be nested, but that the detokenizing process is currently not set up to definitely replace all nested tokens.

        Parameters:

        tokenSpecifier - The specifier for token keys.
        firstResource - The first resource to load.
        additionalResources - Any additional resources to load.

              java.lang.String... additionalResources)

        Parameters:
        firstResource - The first resource to load.
        additionalResources - Any additional resources to load.

    • Method Detail

      • getProperties

        public PropertyDeluxe getProperties(java.lang.String... namespaces)
        Get the PropertyDeluxe instance for the specified namespace. The returned instance contain all of the properties for the specified namespace, and will neither need nor allow the use of any of the namespace names in namespaces.
        Parameters:
        namespaces - The namespace.
        Returns:
        the properties for the namespace specified by namespaces.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the specified namespace is not found.

      • getProperty

        public java.lang.Object getProperty(java.lang.String key,
                           java.lang.String... namespaces)
        Get the property value for a given key and namespace. The returned value will be a String unless its type was specified when the property resources were loaded, or it was set to a non-String value via setProperty(String, Object, String...).
        Parameters:
        key - The property key.
        namespaces - The namespace.
        Returns:
        the property for key in the namespace specified by namespaces.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the specified namespace or key is not found.

      • getString

        public java.lang.String getString(java.lang.String key,
                         java.lang.String... namespaces)
        Get the property value for a given key and namespace as a string. This method returns getProperty(key,namespaces).toString(), which may be different from the value in the property resource, if that value was typed.
        Parameters:
        key - The property key.
        namespaces - The namespace.
        Returns:
        the property for key in the namespace specified by namespaces.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the specified namespace or key is not found.

      • getInt

        public int getInt(java.lang.String key,
         java.lang.String... namespaces)
        Get the property value for a given key and namespace as an integer. If the value was not typed at construction time, then the Integer.parseInt(String) method is used to coerce the value.
        Parameters:
        key - The property key.
        namespaces - The namespace.
        Returns:
        the property for key in the namespace specified by namespaces.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the specified namespace or key is not found, or if the value cannot be coerced into an integer value.

      • getDouble

               java.lang.String... namespaces)

        Parameters:

        namespaces - The namespace.
        Returns:
        the property for key in the namespace specified by namespaces.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the specified namespace or key is not found, or if the value cannot be coerced into a double value.

      • getBoolean

        public boolean getBoolean(java.lang.String key,

        Get the property value for a given key and namespace as a boolean. If the value was not typed at construction time, then the Boolean.parseBoolean(String) method is used to coerce the value.
        Parameters:

        namespaces - The namespace.
        Returns:
        the property for key in the namespace specified by namespaces.
        Throws:

      • getList

        public <E> java.util.List<E> getList(java.lang.String key,
                            java.lang.String... namespaces)
        Get the property value for a given key and namespace as a list. If the value was not typed at construction time, then the value is coerced into a list using the syntax specified in this class' description (sub-typing in this case is not performed).
        Type Parameters:
        E - The type of the elements in the returned list.
        Parameters:
        key - The property key.
        namespaces - The namespace.
        Returns:
        the property for key in the namespace specified by namespaces.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the specified namespace or key is not found, or if the value cannot be coerced into an list.

      • getMap

        public <K,V> java.util.Map<K,V> getMap(java.lang.String key,
                              java.lang.String... namespaces)
        Get the property value for a given key and namespace as a map. If the value was not typed at construction time, then the value is coerced into a map using the syntax specified in this class' description (sub-typing in this case is not performed).
        Type Parameters:
        K - The type of the keys for the returned map.
        V - The type of the values for the returned map.
        Parameters:
        key - The property key.
        namespaces - The namespace.
        Returns:
        the property for key in the namespace specified by namespaces.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the specified namespace or key is not found, or if the value cannot be coerced into an map.

      • setProperty

        public void setProperty(java.lang.String key,
               java.lang.Object value,
               java.lang.String... namespaces)
        Set a property value. Previously defined properties may be replaced, and any type declarations that were made when the property resources were loaded are not enforced.
        Parameters:
        key - The property key.
        value - The property value.
        namespaces - The namespace.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the specified namespace does not exist.

      • formLoadableResource

        public static java.lang.String formLoadableResource(java.lang.String... resourceEntries)
        Form a string that can be used as a loadable resource with the PropertyDeluxe class. This is useful for adding properties as text without having to write them to a file.This method simply joins the resource entries with the '\n' character and returns the result.
        Parameters:
        resourceEntries - The resource entries.
        Returns:
        resourceEntries formatted as a loadable property resource.

      • formLoadableResource

        public static java.lang.String formLoadableResource(java.util.List<java.lang.String> resourceEntries)
        Form a string that can be used as a loadable resource with the PropertyDeluxe class. This is useful for adding properties as text without having to write them to a file.This method simply joins the resource entries with the '\n' character and returns the result.
        Parameters:
        resourceEntries - The resource entries.
        Returns:
        resourceEntries formatted as a loadable property resource.
